question: Question_03_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Use the definition} of convergence for sequences, prove that

\[\lim_{nÂ \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n^2+3n+1}{n^2} = 1.\]
sols:
\textbf{This is the proof as I worked it out, \emph{Solution 2} presents
it as you can polish it and write it nicely to impress your teacher or
nerdy friends.}

I fix myself an $\epsilon > 0$, that means, it's as if I have a fixed
value in my mind like $\epsilon = 0.01$. I need to show that if $n$ is
large enough (that is, larger than some number I call $N_\epsilon$) then
I will have that the term $a_n$ is $\epsilon$-close to my number
\emph{L} (which here I'm already told should be 1). In other words, if
$n$ is large enough, then I should have

\[\displaystyle
|a_n - 1| < \epsilon\]

Here I know the sequence really well, I'm told that

\[a_n = \frac{n^2+3n+1}{n^2}\]

So I can rewrite the not-so-good-looking term $|a_n - 1|$Â~into
something much more presentable by using a little algebra:

\begin{align*}
|a_n - 1| &= \left| \frac{n^2+3n+1}{n^2} - 1 \right|\\
&=\left| \frac{n^2+3n+1}{n^2} - \frac{n^2}{n^2} \right|\\
&= \left| \frac{n^2+3n+1-n^2}{n^2} \right|\\
&= \left| \frac{3n+1}{n^2} \right|\\
\end{align*}

And since $n$ is a positive integer, the above fraction is clearly
always positive so the absolute value is here totally useless. So I'll
rewrite

\[|a_n - 1| = \frac{3n+1}{n^2}\]

Now it seems indeed that I can make this as small as I want as long as
$n$ is large enough. I still need to be precise about this and
explicitly guarantee how big $n$ has to be for the term $|a_n -1|$Â~to
be less than $\epsilon$. Here are two ways to do this:

\textbf{First way:} I can brutally solve

\[\frac{3n+1}{n^2} < \epsilon\] It gives me

\[\displaystyle
3n+1 < \epsilon n^2\] which I can rewrite as

\[\displaystyle
0<\epsilon n^2 -3n-1\] Now since $\epsilon$ is some fixed number, the
above is just a quadratic equation (something like $\epsilon x^2-3x-1$
with an ugly coefficient in front of the $x^2$ term). And since it
corresponds to a positive parabola (I like to think them as
\emph{smiling} parabolas) I know for sure that it will be positive
(above the \emph{x}-axis) for any value larger than its second
\emph{x}-intercept (if there are any \emph{x}-intercepts). The
\emph{x}-intercepts are the solutions of the
equationÂ~$\epsilon x^2 - 3x -1=0$ so using the quadratic formula I find

\[x = \frac{3 \pm \sqrt{9+4\epsilon}}{2\epsilon}\] The larger solution
has to be the one using the "+" sign, so I get that

\[0<\epsilon n^2 -3n-1 \quad\text{if}\quad n > \frac{3 + \sqrt{9+4\epsilon}}{2\epsilon}\]
Which is my $N_\epsilon$. You can try for yourself, if you chose
$\epsilon = 0.01$ then the above gives me $N = 300.33$ and for any value
of $n$ larger than 301 you can see that $(3n+1)/n^2$\textless{} 0.01.

\textbf{Second way:} as so often in math, there is another way that is
easier, but involves being a little bit more smart about all this. Since
I don't care that the value of $N_\epsilon$ is the best possible, just
one that works, I can do the following manipulation

\[\frac{3n+1}{n^2} = \frac{3}{n} + \frac{1}{n^2}\] And now since $n$Â~is
some positive integer, it is always true that $n < n^2$ and hence

\[\frac{1}{n^2}Â < \frac{1}{n}\] Hence

\[\frac{3}{n} + \frac{1}{n^2} < \frac{3}{n} + \frac{1}{n} = \frac{4}{n}\]
And so we get something much simpler to deal with

\[|a_n - 1| = \frac{3n+1}{n^2} < \frac{4}{n}\]

And so now we just wonder when is it true that

\[\frac{4}{n} < \epsilon\] well... clearly when

\[\frac{4}{\epsilon} < n\]

And so for the value $N_\epsilon = 4/\epsilon$ we can guarantee the
convergence of the sequence. You can again verify this for yourself that
if you chose a value $\epsilon=0.01$ then you will get here
$N=400$Â~which we know from the above work is way large enough to
guarantee that for any value of $n$Â~larger than that, we have
$|a_n-1| < 0.01$. In other words this is much simpler, we just lost some
precision on how big the number $N_\epsilon$ has to be, but to prove
convergence, we really don't care so we might as well make our life
easier.

\textbf{Note:} this was the work done \emph{as you go}, which
corresponds to how you would find out how to prove that the given
sequence converges. Now that we have done that work, we can do like
fancy mathematicians and present our work more nicely and concisely. To
see that, check out \textbf{\emph{Solution 2}}.

This is the \emph{polished} proof that we obtained in
\textbf{\emph{Solution 1}} and resembles more what mathematicians
present in books.

Fix a value of $\epsilon >0$ and let

\[N_\epsilon = \frac{4}{\epsilon}\]

Then, if $n >Â N_\epsilon$ it holds that

\begin{align*}
|a_n-1| &= \left| \frac{n^2+3n+1}{n^2}-1\right|\\
&= \frac{3n+1}{n^2}\\
&= \frac{3}{n}Â + \frac{1}{n^2}\\
&< \frac{3}{n} + \frac{1}{n}\\
&= \frac{4}{n}\\
&< \frac{4}{N_\epsilon}\\
&< \epsilon
\end{align*}

which concludes our proof.
hints:
A sequence ${a_n}$ converges to a number \emph{L} if for any
$\epsilon>0$ there exists a number $N_\epsilon$ such that

\[\text{if } n \geq N_\epsilon \quad\text{then}\quad |a_n - L| < \epsilon\]
